questions.question:
Question 1: A 9-month-old infant who has not been previously vaccinated is brought to the OPD. The 
mother is however adamant and is allowing you to inject the baby with only one vaccine. 
Which of the following vaccines would you choose to administer in this situation?
questions.explanation:
In this situation, measles vaccine should be administered subcutaneously because, at 9 months of 
age, it is a priority to give the measles vaccine. OPV and vitamin A should be given orally.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 2: An intern posted in the labour room is administering birth dose vaccines to a newborn baby. 
According to the National Immunization Schedule, which of the following vaccines would he 
not administer?
questions.explanation:
Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) and pentavalent vaccine are not given at birth. The vaccines given 
at birth are BCG, OPV (0 dose) and hepatitis B vaccines.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 3: A farmer residing in West Bengal brings his 16-month-old child to the OPD for routine 
immunization. The child has been adequately immunized till now and has already received a 
measles vaccine during a supplementary immunization activity drive a few months back. 
What will you administer to him now?

options.a: OPV booster, DPT booster and Vitamin A
options.b: OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, JE and Vitamin A
options.c: OPV booster, DPT booster, JE vaccine and Vitamin A
options.d: OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR and Vitamin A

questions.explanation:
Vaccines to be given at 16 months of age are OPV booster, DPT booster, MR, JE, and Vitamin A. The child should receive routine doses of the measles vaccine according to the schedule 
irrespective of the measles supplementary immunisation activity (SIA) dose. So, the second dose 
of the measles vaccine is also given. Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is endemic in rural agricultural areas, often associated with rice 
cultivation and flood irrigation. Vaccination for JE is given in endemic states only. Two doses of a 
live attenuated JE vaccine are given under the Universal Immunisation Programme (UIP) 
schedule. Under the Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) schedule, two doses of a new vero 
cell-derived inactivated JE vaccine are given.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 4: A three and a half-year-old child, who is completely unimmunized, is brought to a PHC. 
Which of the following vaccines can be given to the child now?

options.d: BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vit A

questions.explanation:
DPT-1, OPV-1, measles and vitamin A can be given to this child of 3.5 years of age in his first 
immunization visit. BCG can only be given up to 1 year of age, according to the National Immunisation Schedule 
(NIS). Note: BCG can be given up to 5 years of age, as part of the catch-up immunization schedule which 
is by the Indian Academy of Paediatrics (IAP) and is not followed in government setups. OPV can be given till 5 years of age. Measles can be given till 5 years of age. DPT can be given till 7 years of age (with booster doses). 395 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 5: A 5-year-old girl is brought to your clinic for routine immunization. According to the National 
Immunisation Schedule, which of the following would you administer?
questions.explanation:
At 5 years of age, the 2nd booster dose of DPT must be given along with the 9th (final) dose of 
vitamin A. 1st booster dose of DPT is given at 16 – 24 months of age. 1st dose of vitamin A is given at 9th month and the 2nd dose is given at 16 months followed by 
one dose every 6 months thereafter until the age of 5. Note: DPT booster + Vitamin A is a better answer than DPT booster + OPV because the 9th (final) 
dose of vitamin A must be given at 5 years but OPV at 5 years is an optional vaccine.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 6: A 9-year-old child is brought to the PHC for receiving the JE vaccine. The nurse cleans the 
injection site with a spirit swab and injects the live attenuated JE vaccine subcutaneously on 
the left upper arm. Which of the following statements is true regarding this scenario?

options.a: The procedure of administering the vaccine is wrong
options.b: The site of administering the JE vaccine is inappropriate
options.c: The JE vaccine cannot be administered under routine immunization in a PHC after 2 years of
options.d: Only live attenuated JE vaccine is currently under use

questions.explanation:
The procedure of administration is wrong as it is not advisable to clean the injection site with a 
spirit swab because some of the live components of the vaccine are killed if they come in contact 
with spirit. The child is eligible to receive the Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccine through routine 
immunization till 15 years of age. Live attenuated JE vaccine is administered in the left upper arm 
subcutaneously. JENVAC is a new inactivated vero cell culture derived JE vaccine produced by Bharath Biotech 
International limited in India. It is a Kolar strain-derived vaccine. The recommended dose is 
0.5ml which is given intramuscularly at left anterolateral aspect of midthigh, 4 weeks apart 
starting from 1 year of age. Although a booster dose is recommended at a later period, the 
appropriate time for booster dose administration is not clear. JEEV is another inactivated vero cell culture derived vaccine from the SA-14-14-2 strain. The 
recommended dose is: • 1-3 years: 2 doses of 0.25 ml on 0 and 28 days • >3years, adolescents, and adults: 2 doses of 0.5ml on 0 and 28 days • A booster dose of this vaccine is suggested to be given after 12 months of primary vaccination in 
non-endemic areas. The inactivated vaccines are currently under the recommendation of IAP. Under the Universal 
Immunization Programme (UIP), a live attenuated vaccine is given.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following was launched to ensure complete immunization of children?
questions.explanation:
Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to 
fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely 
unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to 
achieve the same goal by December 2018. 396 
Sold by @itachibot Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 
diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be 
held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month). The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are: • TB • Polio • Hep B • Diphtheria • Pertussis • Tetanus • Measles The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are: • Rotavirus diarrhoea • Rubella (as MR vaccine) • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine) • Pneumococcal meningitis • Japanese Encephalitis The Intensified Mission Indradhanush 2.0: The government of India introduced IMI 2.0 to accelerate the vaccine drive and extend the 
coverage to children and pregnant women in identified districts and blocks from December 2019- 
March 2020. Note: Currently, the government has completed Intensified Mission Indradhanush 5.0: Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI 5.0), the flagship routine immunization campaign of the 
Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare concluded all 3 rounds in October 2023. This is the 
first campaign to be conducted across all the districts in the country and includes children up to 5 
years of age (Previous campaigns included children up to 2 years of age). It also had a special 
focus on improvement of Measles and Rubella vaccination coverage. 397 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 8: You are visiting a rural area for a vaccination drive conducted under the Intensified Mission 
Indradhanush scheme. Which of the following vaccines would you not administer in this 
vaccination drive?
questions.explanation:
Typhoid vaccine is not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. The Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme has been introduced to ensure full immunization 
(>90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (VPDs) (updated 
from the 7 that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be 
held for 7 days each month (from the 7th-13th of each month). The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are: • TB • Polio • Hep B • Diphtheria • Pertussis • Tetanus • Measles The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are: • Rotavirus diarrhoea • Rubella (as MR vaccine) • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine) • Pneumococcal meningitis • Japanese Encephalitis The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) is to reach each and every child under 2 
years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine 398 
Sold by @itachibot immunization coverage.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the National Deworming Programme?

options.a: It is conducted in the months of March and September
options.b: Free tablets are given to children up to the age of 15 years
options.c: It is carried out in schools and anganwadis
options.d: Age appropriate dose of tablet metronidazole is recommended

questions.explanation:
The National Deworming programme is carried out in schools and anganwadis. It is conducted twice a year, in the months of February and August, covering all the children 
from the age of 1 to 19 years. All the children are given age-appropriate dose of tablet albendazole. In the states of Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh, it is carried out only once a year (as the 
prevalence is <20% in these states).
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is true about the National Programme for Prevention and Control of 
Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke?

options.a: No separate centres for stroke, DM and cancer
options.b: Implementation in over 10 districts in 5 states
options.d: Subcentre has facility for diagnosis and treatment

questions.explanation:
District hospital has specialized facilities for the National Programme for Prevention and Control 
of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS). The NPCDCS has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like 
diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 
states. At the subcentre level under NPCDCS, screening and referral are done. Note: The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular 
Diseases and Stroke(NPCDCS) has been changed to the National Programme for Prevention and 
Control of Non-Communicable Diseases(NP-NCD) to include new diseases and new health 
initiatives. The new diseases included in the NP-NCD are: • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease • Chronic Kidney disease 399 
Sold by @itachibot • Asthma and Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease • ST elevation myocardial infarction
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following is a false statement about the Indian Hypertension Control Initiative 
(IHCI)? 385 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The IHCI monitoring personnel includes cardiovascular health officers and senior treatment
options.b: Provision of real-time blood pressure monitoring for all patients via information systems
options.c: The IHCI provides 30-day medication for individuals registered for hypertension management
options.d: The target is a 90% reduction in the prevalence of hypertension by the year 2025

questions.explanation:
The false statement about the Indian Hypertension Control Initiative is a 90% reduction in the 
prevalence of hypertension by the year 2025. The IHCI is an initiative by the MoHFW, WHO, ICMR, and state governments to control 
hypertension in India. It has adopted the goal of “25 by 25” to reduce the prevalence of 
hypertension in India by 25% by 2025. The activities of IHCI are monitored by the cardiovascular 
health officers (CVHO's) at the state and district level and by the senior treatment supervisors 
(STS's) at the sub-district level. The IHCI has strengthened the prevention of hypertension by 
ensuring the provision of antihypertensive medications for 30 days to all patients registered under 
the IHCI. The 5 components of IHCI are: • Use of standardized hypertension treatment protocols approved by national and global policies. • Availability of recommended protocol drugs to provide a regular and uninterrupted supply of 
medications. • Task-sharing and team-based care involving nurses, health workers, and ASHAs to improve 
treatment compliance. • Patient-centered services provide easy access to BP monitoring at Health & wellness centers 
and PHCs. • Information systems that provide real-time BP monitoring to improve patient follow-ups: Use of 
the “Simple App” in all IHCI states. *Note: Amlodipine, telmisartan, and chlorthalidone are the drugs of choice in the standardized 
treatment protocols of the IHCI. 400 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 12: Under the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment, NGO eye 
hospitals are considered as:
questions.explanation:
NGO eye hospitals are considered secondary level centres under the National Programme for 
Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI). Levels of eye care centres according to NPCBVI: • Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centres, mobile ophthalmic units, 
upgraded PHCs, and link workers. • Secondary level: District hospitals and NGO eye hospitals. • Tertiary level: Regional institutes of ophthalmology and medical colleges. The goal of NPCBVI is to reduce the prevalence of blindness to 0.25% by 2025.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following is used to measure the output of the National Programme for Control 
of Blindness & Visual Impairment?

options.a: Number of cases of refractory errors corrected
options.b: Number of cataract surgeries leading to sight restoration
options.c: Number of cases of childhood blindness detected and cured
options.d: Prevalence of blindness reduced by 0.5% per year

questions.explanation:
The measure of the output of the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual 
Impairment (NPCBVI) is indicated by the number of cataract surgeries leading to sight 
restoration. The most common cause of low vision in India is cataract (low vision is visual acuity <6/18- 
6/60).
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following diseases is not a part of the Vision 2020 programme in India?
questions.explanation:
Onchocerciasis is not a part of the Vision 2020 programme in India. It is a part of the Global 
Vision 2020 programme. 401 
Sold by @itachibot Global Vision 2020 
India Vision 2020 CataractRefractive errors and 
low visionChildhood blindne 
ss CataractRefractive errors and 
low visionChildhood blindne 
ssTrachoma Onchocerciasis 
Glaucoma Diabetic Retinopathy Corneal blindness
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 15: 386 
Sold by @itachibot A pregnant woman from a rural area registers under Janani Suraksha Yojana. Which of the 
following services would not be provided to her under this scheme?

options.a: Safe motherhood services under Vandematharam scheme

questions.explanation:
The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) does not provide STD counseling. Janani Suraksha Yojana is a safe motherhood intervention launched under National Rural Health 
Mission (NRHM) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery 
among poor pregnant women. The services provided by the JSY are: • Cash is disbursed to the mother at the institution for having an institutional delivery. • Safe motherhood services (IFA tablets, TT vaccination) under the Vandemataram scheme. • Village health and nutrition day • Maternal death review • Pregnancy tracking: ASHA worker/Anganwadi Worker (AWW) or any other link worker help in 
monitoring antenatal check-ups, and post-delivery care. • Safe abortion services: mifepristone followed by misoprostol and manual vacuum aspiration.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 16: Where and how often is the Village Health Nutrition Day conducted?

options.c: Once every two weeks in PHC
options.d: Once every two weeks in Anganwadi

questions.explanation:
Village Health Nutrition Day is conducted once a month in the Anganwadi centres in the village 
itself. The villagers interact with health workers and are provided with basic services and 
information about health care.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 17: A 20-day old baby is gasping for air and not feeding properly. The mother has no money to go 
to the nearby hospital. Which national programme has provisions to benefit this woman to 
take her baby to the health facility?
questions.explanation:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant 
women and sick infants from: • home to the health facilities • between facilities in case of a referral • back home from the health facilities The provisions of JSSK include: 402 
Sold by @itachibot • Free transport • Free treatment • Free drugs and consumables • Free diagnostics and diet • Free and cashless delivery • Free C-Section • Free provision of blood Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 
days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 18: The Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram was designed for which of the following demographic 
groups?
questions.explanation:
The Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) was designed to train health personnel in basic 
newborn care and resuscitation. The training is aimed to improve the delivery of excellent newborn care at every point and is 
usually done for 2 days.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 19: A 10-year-old girl has just started menstruating. Under which of the following national 
programmes, she will be provided with a pack of sanitary napkins by the ASHA worker in her 
village?
questions.explanation:
The girl will be provided with a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the 
ASHA worker through the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme under the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya 
Karyakram (RKSK). RKSK focuses on: • Development of adolescent population (10-19 years). • Weekly Iron and Folic Acid supplementation (100mg Fe + 500 mcg Folic Acid) • Menstrual hygiene: A pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA. • It also includes enhancement of mental health and prevention of substance abuse and violence. Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana is a government-sponsored savings program for parents of girl 
children <10 years age. It helps parents to set aside money for their female child’s potential 
college and marriage expenses by opening an account at any post office branch or any commercial 
bank approved by the central government. Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) seeks to empower adolescent girls, so as to enable them to take 
charge of their lives. The objectives are to: • improve the nutritional, health and development status of adolescent girls • promote awareness of health, hygiene, nutrition and family care • opportunities for learning life skills 403 
Sold by @itachibot • going back to school • help them gain a better understanding of their social environment • take initiatives to become productive members of society. Recent update: Department of Pharmaceuticals under Ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers has 
recently launched ‘Suvidha’ (100% Oxo-biodegradable Sanitary Napkin), under the Pradhan 
Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) on World menstrual hygiene day. ‘Swachhta, 
Swasthya and Suvidha’ will be available for Rs. 1 per pad over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendras for the 
underprivileged women of India.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 20: Which among the following is not true about POSHAN Abhiyan?

options.a: It is a programme of the Ministry of Women and Child Development
options.b: The goals are to achieve improvement in neonatal mortality
options.c: Launched on the date of International Women's Day 2018
options.d: Targets to reduce low birth weight by 2% per annum

questions.explanation:
The goal of POSHAN Abhiyaan /National Nutrition Mission (NNM) is to achieve an improvement 
in the nutritional status during the next three years beginning 2017-18. It is a flagship programme 
of the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD). Its target population include: • children from 0-6 years • adolescent girls • pregnant women • lactating mothers The logo is: 404 
Sold by @itachibot The following image depicts the targets of this mission: Note: Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government scheme in India to provide Rs.500 per month for 
TB patients to buy food.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is the objective of the Ujjawala Scheme?

options.a: Provide LPG connections to families below poverty line
options.d: Provide LED bulbs in every household

questions.explanation:
The Ujjawala Scheme is for the prevention of trafficking and for the rescue, rehabilitation, and 
reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation. The Ujjwala Yojana (note spelling without "a") is for providing 5 crores of free cooking LPG 
connections to all families below the poverty line till 2019. The Ujala Scheme (Unnat Jyoti by Affordable LEDs and Appliances for All) is the largest domestic 
lighting project in the world, launched under the Ministry of Power. It aims at promoting the use 405 
Sold by @itachibot of energy-efficient LED bulbs in every household in the country. INSPIRE strategy is a set of 7 evidence-based strategies introduced to select, implement, monitor, 
and evaluate effective policies, programs, and services to prevent and respond to violence against 
children.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 22: An ASHA worker is offering services under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in her village. All of 
the following services will be provided by her except:

options.d: Information, education, communication and public awareness

questions.explanation:
Water pollution is not managed under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan. The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was launched in 2014 with an aim to eradicate open-air defecation by 
the year 2019 through the construction of 12 million toilets. The two sub-missions of Swachh 
Bharat Abhiyan are Swachh Bharat Mission Gramin (SBM-G) and Swachh Bharat Mission Urban 
(SBM-U). • Components of this mission include: • Household toilets including improving unsanitary latrines • Community toilets • Public toilets • Solid waste management • Information, education, communication, and public awareness • Capacity building and administrative & office expenses
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 23: Which of the following statements is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health 
Protection Mission?

options.a: Government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year
options.b: The limit of the family size that is covered is up to 7 members
options.c: All pre-existing diseases of the individual are covered
options.d: It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization

questions.explanation:
There is no cap on family size or the age of the members. All the families listed under the 
Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database are covered as per the defined criteria. The following are the benefits provided under this program: • Health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year. • All families listed in the SECC database, as per the defined criteria, will be covered. There is no 
cap on family size and age of members. • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals • Both secondary and tertiary care hospitalization is covered. • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment. • To control costs, the payments for treatment will be done on a package rate (to be defined by the 
Government in advance) basis. • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services. Logo: 406 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following statements is true regarding Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana?

options.a: Unemployment allowance is not given in case of closure of factory
options.b: Unemployment allowance is given in case of employment injury
options.c: Allowance is given at 50% of the daily wage for a maximum of 2 years
options.d: To qualify for the scheme, worker must have worked for more than 2 years

questions.explanation:
Unemployment allowance under Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana (RGSKY) is given at the 
rate of 50% of daily wage for a maximum of 2 years. RGSKY is a scheme of ESI that provides unemployment allowance to an insured person going out 
of employment involuntarily, on account of: • closure of a factory or establishment • retrenchment (laying off employees due to economic difficulty) • permanent disability due to nonemployment injury Allowance and eligibility criteria of Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana (updated in 2019): • The allowance is given at the rate of 50% of the daily wage for a maximum of 2 years. 407 
Sold by @itachibot • To qualify for the scheme the worker must have worked in that setup for >3 years. Note: Disability due to employment injury is covered under disablement benefits of ESI Act, 1948. • Temporary disability: 90% of wages until disablement lasts. • Permanent disability: 90% of wages as a life pension on the basis of loss of earning capacity. • Dependants benefit: 90% of wage as monthly payment to the dependants of the deceased 
person, in cases where death occurs due to employment injury or occupational hazards.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 25: Which of the following does the Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of 
India refer to?

options.a: Initiative for providing free sanitary pads
options.b: Initiative to provide vaccination to under-5 children
options.c: Initiative for labour room quality improvement
options.d: Initiative to provide affordable healthcare to all

questions.explanation:
The Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refers to the initiative for 
labour room quality improvement. There is enough evidence to support the fact that improving the quality of care in labour rooms, 
especially on the day of birth, is crucial to maternal and neonatal survival. Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care being provided to the pregnant mother in the 
labour room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse 
outcomes associated with childbirth. This initiative is implemented in government medical 
colleges besides district hospitals, and high delivery load sub-district hospitals, and community 
health centres. It plans to conduct quality certification of labour rooms and also incentivize facilities achieving 
the targets outlined. The goal is to reduce preventable maternal and new-born mortality, 
morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in labour room and maternity 
OT, and ensure respectful maternity care.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 26: The image below shows the logo of which of the following national programmes? 389 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shown is the new logo of the 360-degree holistic Family Planning Campaign. Logo of other options: 408 
Sold by @itachibot "Beti bachao Beti padhao." Indla wewborn Action
 Plan India Newborn Action Plan (INAP) 409 
Sold by @itachibot The logo of Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (JSSK)
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 27: What is the main objective of the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Jan-aushadhi Pariyojana?

options.a: Improve maternal and child health services
options.b: Make quality, generic medicines affordable to all
options.c: Enhance quality of life and increase employment for the differently abled
options.d: Promote cleanliness and enhance quality of healthcare facilities in India

questions.explanation:
The Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Jan-aushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) carries the objective of making 
quality, generic medicines affordable for everyone, especially the lower socio-economic groups. BPPI (Bureau of Pharma PSUs of India), under the Ministry of Chemicals & Fertilizers, is the 
implementation agency for PMBJP. The mission of this programme includes creating awareness 
and demand for generic medicines through education and supply of such medications. Kayakalp programme is a national initiative launched by the Ministry of Health and Family 
Welfare (MoHFW) under Swachh Bharat Abhiyan to promote cleanliness and enhance the quality 
of healthcare facilities in India. 410 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 28: The Mid Day Meal Programme aims to supplement:
questions.explanation:
Under the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) scheme, supplementary nutrition provided must cover at 
least 1/2 of total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of total daily energy requirement of children 
in schools. The MDM scheme is also called School Lunch Programme and has been operational since 1961 in 
India. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the Minimum Needs Programme. Some other principles of the MDM are: • The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home 
diets. • The cost of meals should be reasonably low. • The meal should be easy to cook in schools. • Locally available foods must be used, for as far as possible. • The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony. Note: In September 2021, the Mid-Day Meal Scheme was renamed PM POSHAN or Pradhan 
Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 29: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the Vandematharam scheme?

options.b: Its aim is to provide safe motherhood services
options.c: An MBBS graduate or an obstetrician can volunteer
options.d: IFA tablets and TT injections are provided by District Medical Officers

questions.explanation:
The Vandematharam scheme does not include free treatment in private clinics. Vandematharam scheme is a voluntary scheme for providing safe motherhood services. It can be 
volunteered by an obstetrician, maternity home, nursing home, lady doctor or an MBBS graduate. IFA tablets, OCPs, and TT injections are provided by the respective District Medical Officers 
(DMOs) to the Vandematharam doctors or clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries. Cases 
needing special care and treatment can be referred to government hospitals.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 30: Which of the following is a component of the scheme depicted by the logo given below?
questions.explanation:
National Health Protection Mission is a component of the Ayushman Bharat scheme. Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) aims to build a comprehensive 
need-based health care service and targets to build a 'New India 2022'. Its components are: • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- these centres will provide Comprehensive 
Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and 
non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services. • National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) provides health protection cover to poor and 
vulnerable families, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization 
cases among others. 411 
Sold by @itachibot Beneficiary Level: • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year. • All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per defined criteria 
will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members. • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens. • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals in times of need. • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization. • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, 
and diagnostics. • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment. • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services. • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the 
treatment. • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline 
number. 412 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 31: Which of the following vaccines has not been introduced to the immunization programme in 
India?
questions.explanation:
Influenza vaccine (Flu shot) has not been introduced to the National Immunization Programme in 
India. The Influenza vaccine provides protection against viral flu caused by the influenza virus. Note: Bacterial Hemophilus influenzae type-b (Hib) vaccine is different from the viral influenza 
(Flu) vaccine. HiB is a part of the pentavalent vaccine.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 32: The POCSO Act is related to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act is related to child sexual abuse. POCSO Act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines different forms of 
sexual abuse, including penetrative and non-penetrative assault, as well as sexual harassment and 
pornography. The Act deems a sexual assault to be "aggravated" under certain circumstances, such as when the 
abused child is mentally ill or when the abuse is committed by a person in a position of trust or 
authority vis-à-vis the child, like a family member, police officer, teacher, or doctor. People who traffic children for sexual purposes are also punishable under the provisions relating 
to abetment in the Act. The Act prescribes stringent punishment graded as per the gravity of the 
offence, with a maximum term of rigorous imprisonment for life and a fine.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 33: Mass drug administration is not done for which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Mass drug administration is not done in case of vitamin A deficiency. 413 
Sold by @itachibot Mass Drug Administration (MDA) is the administration of a drug to an entire concerned 
population irrespective of age and gender. For example, antimalarials are given as MDA in 
malaria-endemic island communities and in low-endemic non-island settings approaching 
elimination, where there is minimal risk of re-introduction of infection, good access to treatment, 
and implementation of vector control and surveillance. Vitamin A prophylaxis is given under National Immunization Schedule (NIS) only to children up 
to 5 years. It is given as mass prophylaxis and not as a drug for treatment. Vitamin A as a 
treatment is given only to a child with features of vitamin A deficiency and such doses are not 
instituted to everyone in the community. Therefore, it is not considered under MDA. On the other hand, MDA is done in scabies (ivermectin), worm infestation (albendazole), and 
filariasis (DEC + albendazole).
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question: Question 34: Monetary benefit is measured in which of the following analyses?
questions.explanation:
The monetary benefit is measured in a cost-benefit analysis. In cost-benefit analysis, the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the 
program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to determine whether a given programme 
is economically sound and to select the best out of several alternate programmes. The main drawback with this technique is that the benefits in the health field, as a result of a 
particular programme, cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. We generally express the 
benefit in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome. In cost-effective analysis, the benefit is expressed in terms of results achieved. (Eg: number of 
lives saved or number of days free from disease). Input-output analysis: how much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the 
health field, input refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, 
money, materials, and time); and output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives 
saved, or inoculations performed. Network analysis: a network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order 
to reach an end objective. Management Methods in Health Programmes: Methods based on behavioral Quantitative methods sciences Cost–Benefit analysisCost-Eff 
ective analysisCost–Accounti

questions.question: Question 35: As per NCEP- ATP III, which of the following is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
As per NCEP- ATP III, high LDL is not included in the definition criteria of metabolic syndrome. Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is 
given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III). 
It includes: • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F) • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level  150 mg/dL • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively. • Hypertension: blood pressure 130 mmHg systolic or  85 mmHg diastolic. • Fasting plasma glucose level: 100 mg/dL or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 36: In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality 
Ratio by 2030 to  
 (per 1 lakh live births):
questions.explanation:
In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 
2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births. There are 17 global goals and 169 targets set for 2030 as part of the official Sustainable 
Development Goals of the Agenda 2030.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 37: As per the new National Policy for Rare Diseases, financial support of up to Rs. 20 lakhs can 
be given to which group of rare diseases?
questions.explanation:
415 
Sold by @itachibot As per the new National Policy for Rare Diseases, a provision for financial support of up to Rs. 20 
lakhs under the umbrella scheme of Rashtriya Arogya Nidhi is proposed for the treatment of rare 
diseases that require a one-time treatment (listed under Group 1 in the rare disease policy). National Policy for Rare Diseases is a comprehensive policy for the prevention and management 
of rare diseases. The policy lists rare diseases under 3 groups: • Group 1: Disorders amenable to one-time curative treatment: • Disorders amenable to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation eg: lysosomal storage disorders • Disorders amenable to organ transplantation eg: glycogen storage disorders, urea cycle 
disorders, ADPKD, etc. • Group 2: Diseases requiring long term/ lifelong treatment having a relatively lower cost of 
treatment: • This group includes disorders managed with special dietary formulae/ hormone/ specific drugs. 
eg: phenylketonuria, osteogenesis imperfecta, etc. • Group 3: Diseases for which definitive treatment is available but treatment is lifelong or 
expensive: • This group includes diseases such as Pompe disease, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, etc. The objectives of the policy are: • Lowering the high cost of treatment for rare diseases with an increased focus on indigenous 
research. • Creating a national hospital-based registry of rare diseases. • Early screening and prevention through primary and secondary health care infrastructure, and 
through counselling for the high-risk parents. • Crowdfunding mechanism in which corporates and individuals will be encouraged to extend 
financial support.
questions.chapter_heading: National Health Programmes III - NIS  JSY  RBSK

questions.question:
Question 38: You are a medical officer at a PHC. Which of the following would you advise for mass 
prophylaxis/ treatment for anemia?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, FeSO4 + vitamin C + Folate + vitamin B12 may be considered for mass 
prophylaxis against anemia. Vit C enhances the absorption of iron from the stomach by acting as a reducing substance. Subclinical folate deficiency is seen in up to 30% of North Indian pregnant women. Moreover, it 
may be masked by widespread iron deficiency. It is, for this reason, iron and folate 
supplementation is carried out in national programmes. Clinical vitamin B12 deficiency is not commonly encountered, but subclinical cases might be seen 
in up to 30% of adults and children due to widespread restriction to consumption of vegetarian 
products only. Hence supplementing vitamin B12 is a good idea provided the cost factor is not an 
issue. Option B: Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose was marketed as being superior to iron sulfate in terms 
of efficacy, but it lacked any data to back up the evidence. 416 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Ferrous fumarate may be considered for the treatment of iron deficiency anemia with 
similar efficacy as that of ferrous sulfate. Option D: Injection iron sucrose or any parenteral form is not used as a first-line option. It is only 
indicated if the oral form is not tolerated. 417 
Sold by @itachibot Demography I: Demographic Cycle, Annual Growth Rate and Age Pyramid
